items.name: Magical Items (Adv.)
items.description: Determines the type of magical item found, such as a Potion, Scroll, Wand, or Sword.

items.name: Desert Encounter
items.description:
Desert Encounter

  • Clear daylight [[4d6*10]] yards

  • Dim Light* [[2d6*10]] yards

  • No light † [[1d4*10]] yards

* Or full darkness with infravision used.

† Or very poor visibility (heavy snow or fog, sandstorm, etc.).

results.text: Pursue: The men will chase the party off the lord's land or charge the characters a toll. This sum may vary depending on the personality of the lord, how wealthy the characters look, and other factors. Refusing to pay may result in the PCs being arrested, run off the land, or attacked. The DM can ignore this result if the castle owner is Lawful and the PCs have behaved well.
Ignore: No attempt is made to aid or hinder the party.
Friendly: The castle owner invites the party to stay. (This is not necessarily actual friendship; some NPCs may have evil intentions toward the unsuspecting party.)

items.name: Swords (Basic)
items.description: Generates a specific magical sword, including short, normal, bastard, and two-handed types, with bonuses or special effects.

results.text: [[1d6]] Gems. Worth [[/r 1d6*50 #Gold piece value of gem]] gold pieces each. Roll for each gem separately.

[[1d8]] Jewelry. Worth [[/r 1d8*50 #Gold piece value of jewelry]] gold pieces each. Roll for each item of jewelry separately.  @Compendium[fade-compendiums.roll-table-compendium.RollTable.YTfrzt8Tsat7r6BU]

results.text: Pursue: The men will chase the party off the lord's land or charge the characters a toll. This sum may vary depending on the personality of the lord, how wealthy the characters look, and other factors. Refusing to pay may result in the PCs being arrested, run off the land, or attacked. The DM can ignore this result if the castle owner is Lawful and the PCs have behaved well.
Ignore: No attempt is made to aid or hinder the party.
Friendly: The castle owner invites the party to stay. (This is not necessarily actual friendship; some NPCs may have evil intentions toward the unsuspecting party.)
A dungeon feature (such as stairs, a room, a door, a monster, treasure, etc.) is not actually present but is merely a phantasm.

A shifting wall moves after the party passes, cutting off their exit. They must find another way out of the dungeon. The wall will shift back after a duration determined by a roll of [[/r 1d6]]: on a roll of 1-2, it will shift back in one turn; on a roll of 3-5, it will shift back in one hour; and on a roll of 6, it will shift back in one day.

The room (or stairs, or door, or item) moves (turns, drops, closes, rises, etc.) unexpectedly. It might be stopped if a Dexterity check is made, with a penalty of +1, +2, or +3 to the die roll, indicating that the party reacts quickly enough to prevent it.

The room contains a seemingly bottomless pool in the center of the room. Roll the Magic Pool table only after one or more characters commit to drinking from it. @Compendium[fade-compendiums.roll-table-compendium.RollTable.SxLgCljhvJfybE5j]

The room (or item, or treasure) emits strange noises, such as moaning, screaming, or whispering voices. These unsettling sounds can create an eerie atmosphere, potentially causing unease or fear among the characters. The source of the noises may be a mystery, leading to further investigation or caution as they explore the area.

A large statue of a person, monster, or gadget is found in the room. It may be valuable, magical, or too heavy to move. The statue could be alive, lonesome, and willing to talk—though it may not always tell the truth. It might also be concealing a trapdoor, hiding treasure, or serving as a guardian for something more significant. The presence of the statue invites curiosity and caution, as its true nature and purpose remain uncertain.

This feature could be a trapdoor leading up or down, secret stairs hidden behind a false wall, or an elevator that operates mysteriously. It may also be a magical portal that transports characters to another room, a different level, or even an entirely separate dungeon. The method of transportation may require a specific action, a key, or a magical incantation to activate, adding an element of intrigue and exploration to the environment.

This applies to any variation of a listed monster, such as a skeleton that shoots its fingertips like a Magic Missile, a two-headed giant ogre, or a "goop" dragon that spits green slime or gray ooze. It could also include a wild bore (a shaggy man who tells long, dreary stories), a quarterling (a half-sized halfling), or a Mouth Harpy (who can't sing but plays the harmonica). Other examples might be an Ogre Jelly (which looks like an ogre but has unusual properties) or a Rock and Roll Baboon. These unique variations add creativity and unpredictability to encounters, challenging players to adapt their strategies.

Let your imagination run wild by including unusual elements such as weapons that fly and attack on their own, talking skulls that offer cryptic advice, or a magic item or treasure firmly stuck to the floor, wall, or ceiling. You might introduce a magical area with effects like zero gravity, reversed gravity, growth to double size, or shrinking to 1 inch tall, with the effect lasting until leaving the area. Additionally, consider placing a huge creature recently slain, too large to fit through the corridors—prompting the question, "But how did it get here?" These bizarre features can enhance the atmosphere and intrigue of the dungeon, encouraging exploration and creativity.

The room is filled with a faint, glowing mist that obscures vision beyond 10 feet. Characters moving through it feel a tingling sensation. The mist might conceal a hidden object, a trap, or a creature, and its effects (if any) are revealed only after prolonged exposure or a specific action.

A large, cracked mirror dominates one wall. Anyone gazing into it sees their reflection subtly altered—older, younger, or as a different creature. Interacting with the mirror might trigger a magical effect, reveal a clue, or require a Wisdom check to avoid a minor curse.

The floor is covered in a mosaic depicting a forgotten battle or ritual. Stepping on specific tiles causes them to glow or emit a sound, possibly activating a mechanism, revealing a secret, or summoning a spectral image tied to the mosaic’s story.

A faint breeze carries the scent of flowers or decay through the room, though no source is visible. The air seems to whisper faintly, and characters with high Intelligence might discern a pattern or message in the sounds, leading to a hidden passage or warning.

The room’s walls are lined with shelves holding dozens of dusty tomes or scrolls. Most are mundane, but one or two might contain a minor spell, a map, or a riddle. Reading them takes time, and there’s a chance of triggering a trap or attracting unwanted attention.

A single, ornate chair sits in the center of the room, carved with strange runes. Sitting in it causes a sensation of warmth or cold, and the character might hear a telepathic voice offering cryptic advice, a warning, or a demand before fading away.

The ceiling is covered in faintly glowing crystals that pulse in a slow rhythm. Touching or striking them might cause them to dim, brighten, or release a harmless burst of light or sound, possibly alerting nearby creatures or revealing a hidden feature.

A small fountain bubbles in the corner, its water unnaturally clear. Drinking from it requires a Constitution check; success might grant a temporary boon (like +1 to a stat for an hour), while failure could cause nausea or a minor magical effect.

The room’s temperature is unnaturally hot or cold, causing discomfort. Prolonged exposure (more than a turn) requires a Constitution check to avoid fatigue or minor damage. The source might be magical or environmental, and neutralizing it could yield a reward.

A large, rusted cage sits in the room, its door slightly ajar. It’s empty, but claw marks and faint bloodstains suggest something escaped. The cage might be trapped, contain a hidden compartment, or serve as a clue to a nearby creature stalking the dungeon.

Characters become frightened and flee for [[/r 1d6]] rounds.
Characters stink badly for [[/r 1d6]] turns, increasing Wandering Monster chance by 1.
Characters become enraged and attack allies for [[/r 1d4]] rounds.
Characters become paralyzed (as the spell) for [[/r 1d4]] rounds.

items.name: NPC Reaction
items.description: Most parties (whether NPCs or PCs) will not want to fight other parties, preferring monsters to challenge. The DM may wish to avoid the large, complicated battle that could occur between two parties. When PCs meet an NPC party, decide how the: NPCs will react, or roll a reaction. Modify the roll if you choose (perhaps the NPCs have heard of the PC party, or are even familiar with them as allies, rivals, or enemies).

results.text: Offer to buy or sell information [[1d100*5]] gp

items.name: NPC Adventurer Class
items.description: *In campaigns where Underworld races are common, a duergar, drow, or svirfneblin may be encountered in place of a dwarf, elf, or gnome.

items.name: Castle Encounter
items.description:
The DM can determine the character class of castle inhabitants either by using the Subtable: Castle Encounters (page 98) or by selecting classes as appropriate. If the table is to be used, roll a 1d6; if the result is a 3, roll 1d6 again and see which of the demihuman races is the result. For human owners of a castle, regardless of class, roll 1d20 + 8 for the owner's level. Demihuman levels are listed in the table.

If the DM has not already determined what the castle inhabitants' reactions will be to player characters, he or she can either check the Monster Reactions Table given earlier in this chapter or check the Castle Reactions Table on page 99. The "Reaction" columns of the table assume that the party does nothing to either arouse suspicion or to inspire trust; the DM can certainly adjust the die roll if the PCs' actions toward the castle inhabitants warrant the modification.

Remember, too, that some high-level PC fighters may have the right of sanctuary at castles in the campaign; a PC with that right who declares his name and title will normally receive a "Friendly" result.

Note that the men listed are only part of the castle owner's forces and are simply the unit sent out after annoying travelers; the rest of the castle's forces should include other men and might even include special monsters.

Pursue: The men will chase the party off the lord's land or charge the characters a toll. This sum may vary depending on the personality of the lord, how wealthy the characters look, and other factors. Refusing to pay may result in the PCs being arrested, run off the land, or attacked. The DM can ignore this result if the castle owner is Lawful and the PCs have behaved well.

Ignore: No attempt is made to aid or hinder the party.

Friendly: The castle owner invites the party to stay. (This is not necessarily actual friendship; some NPCs may have evil intentions toward the unsuspecting party.)

results.text: If the adventurers are annoying, a patrol of [[2d6]] heavy footmen are sent after them
If the adventurers are annoying, a patrol of [[2d6]] heavy horsemen are sent after them
If the adventurers are annoying, a patrol of [[2d6]] medium horsemen are sent after them
If the adventurers are annoying, a patrol of [[2d6]] demihumans are sent after them

Wine, rare: Encumbrance [[1d6 + 3]] * 10 cn per bottle, Value [[1d6]] gp/bottle.

items.description: A table to determine special treasure values, encumbrances (in cn), and notes for various items.

results.text: The door is both locked and stuck shut
Door is unlocked, but stuck shut

items.name: Misc. Weapons (Class B)
items.description: Determines the magic bonus and chance of additional modifiers for Class B weapons.

items.name: Magic Pool
items.description: The liquid from the pools is only magical while within 5' of the pool itself.

results.text: Pool of Rejuvenation: This shimmering blue water restores 1d4 hit points when ingested. Additionally, it removes one level of exhaustion. The pool can only be used once per day by each character.
Pool of Illusions: This clear water creates a vivid illusion of a treasure or creature when looked into. The illusion lasts for 1 hour and can be interacted with, but it is not real.

Pool of Transformation: Drinking from this pool causes the drinker to transform into a random creature (determined by the DM) for 1d6 hours. The transformation is complete, including abilities and appearance.
Pool of Time Dilation: Characters who enter this pool experience time differently. For every minute spent in the pool, only 10 seconds pass outside. This effect lasts for 1 hour.
Pool of Shadows: This dark, murky water grants the ability to become invisible for 1d4 minutes after drinking. However, any noise made while invisible will reveal the drinker’s location.
Pool of Elemental Fury: This pool contains swirling elemental energies. Drinking from it allows the character to cast a random elemental spell (fire, ice, lightning, etc.) once within the next hour.

Pool of Memory: This pool allows a character to recall any one memory from their past as if it were happening again. This effect can be used to gain insight or inspiration, granting advantage on the next skill check.
Pool of Growth: Drinking from this pool causes the drinker to grow 1d4 inches taller for 1 hour. During this time, they gain a +1 bonus to Strength checks but suffer a -1 penalty to Dexterity checks.

Pool of Nightmares: This pool is filled with dark, swirling liquid. Drinking from it causes the character to experience vivid nightmares, resulting in disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws for the next 24 hours.
Pool of Echoes: This pool amplifies sound. Any noise made within 30 feet of the pool is doubled in volume, which can be used strategically to distract or alert nearby creatures.

Pool of Clarity: Drinking from this pool clears the mind, granting advantage on Intelligence checks and saving throws for 1 hour. However, the drinker must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or become overwhelmed by clarity, suffering disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws.
Pool of Binding: This pool contains a viscous liquid that, when touched, binds the character's hands together for 1d4 minutes. During this time, they cannot use their hands for any actions.

Pool of Whispers: This pool allows the drinker to hear the thoughts of nearby creatures for 1d6 minutes. The drinker must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw to avoid becoming overwhelmed by the flood of thoughts.
Pool of Fortitude: Drinking from this pool grants temporary hit points equal to 1d6 + the character's level. These hit points last for 1 hour or until depleted.

Pool of the Ancients: This ancient-looking pool grants the drinker knowledge of one spell of their choice from any class for 1 hour. The spell can be cast once during this time without expending a spell slot.
Pool of the Beast: Drinking from this pool allows the character to communicate with animals for 1d4 hours. They can understand and speak to any animal within 30 feet.
Pool of the Lost: This pool shows visions of lost or hidden treasures when gazed into. The drinker must succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw to remember the location after leaving the pool.

Pool of the Elements: This pool changes its properties based on the season. In winter, it grants cold resistance; in spring, it heals; in summer, it grants fire resistance; and in autumn, it provides advantage on stealth checks.
Pool of the Forgotten: Drinking from this pool causes the drinker to forget one random spell or ability for 24 hours. They cannot use the forgotten ability until the time has passed.

Pool of the Phoenix: This pool contains fiery red liquid that, when ingested, allows the drinker to be revived once after death within the next 24 hours. The drinker must still make a saving throw to avoid death in the first place.

Pool of Venom: This pool contains a thick, dark green liquid that bubbles gently, giving off a faint, acrid aroma. The surface shimmers with an oily sheen, reflecting light in unsettling patterns. Any creature that touches or drinks from this pool must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature suffers 2d6 poison damage and is poisoned for 1 hour, experiencing nausea and disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks. Even a single drop on the tongue will cause a burning sensation and inflict 1d6 poison damage, with no saving throw allowed. The pool appears to be bottomless, and any attempt to remove the liquid results in it evaporating into a harmless mist.
The pool is crystal clear water that can be consumed with no side-effects.

items.name: Giant Control
items.description: Determines the type of giant controlled, such as Hill, Frost, or Storm Giant.

results.text: NPC Party. One character of name level or greater, plus [[2d10]] low-level apprentices.

items.name: Trap Type
items.description: A hidden trap is set in the room. If treasure is present, the trap likely guards it; otherwise, it's placed near an exit or underfoot.

results.text: A blade sweeps out from a wall, floor, or ceiling, striking a character for [[/r 1d6]] physical damage. A successful Saving Throw vs. Wands check avoids the hit.

A spring-loaded mechanism fires a volley of tiny darts. Each affected character must make a Saving Throw vs. Wands or take [[/r 1d4]] physical damage. Some darts may be poisoned; fail a Save vs. Poison and take an additional [[/r 1d6]] poison damage unless the character makes a saving vs poison.
Triggering this trap sets off an explosion, dealing [[/r 2d4]] fire damage to all creatures in a 10' radius. A successful Saving Throw vs. Wands check halves the damage.
When triggered, a heavy block or rubble falls from above. Affected characters must Save vs. Wands or take [[/r 1d8]] physical damage from the impact.
Triggering the trap in this room releases a strange fog. All in the area must Save vs. Spells or suffer one of the following effects:

If there's treasure, the illusion guards it; otherwise, it's placed near an exit or misleading floor section. When triggered, an illusory scene appears—perhaps a phantom monster, false treasure, or a vanishing floor. Characters may Save vs. Spells to disbelieve. Failure may cause panic, missteps into real danger, or lure the party toward another trap.

Triggering this trap causes a sudden flash of blinding light. All creatures who see it must Save vs. Spells or be blinded for [[/r 1d4]] turns. While blinded, characters suffer -4 to attack rolls and cannot cast spells requiring sight.
A section of the floor gives way, and one, some, or all characters must make a Dexterity check to see if they can avoid falling in.

A poison gas is either already in the room or blown into the room. Victims make Saving Throws against Poison or take damage (1d4, 1d6, or whatever is dangerous but not deadly to most characters). Optionally, a Saving Throw against Poison with bonuses (+1, +2, +4) to the roll may be made, with failure resulting in death. The gas is usually contained and released when a container is opened.

A small needle is hidden somewhere and is nearly undetectable until accidentally touched. When triggered, it will spring out and poke a character who tries to open something. The character can make a Saving Throw against poison; on failure, they suffer [[/r 1d6]] poison damage.

items.name: Intelligence of Sword

results.text:
Sword Intelligence
INT: 12
Communication: Speech
Languages: [[2d4]]
Powers: 3 Primary + Reads Magic + 1 Extraordinary

items.description: Determines the intelligence, communication abilities, languages, and powers of a magical sword. If primary or extraordinary powers are indicated, roll on the Primary and Extraordinary Powers tables.

items.name: Weapons Add. Mod. 25%
items.description: Determines if a weapon has an additional modifier. Roll on the Additional Weapon Mods (Misc) table if successful.

items.name: Ointment Type

results.text: Blessing: This salve gives the recipient a -2 bonus to armor class and a +2 bonus to all saving throws for 1 turn.
Healing: This salve cures [[/r 2d6+2 #points of damage cured]] points of damage.
Poison: This salve seems to be an ointment of blessing, but it is a poison. The recipient must make a saving throw vs. poison, with a -2 penalty to the roll, or die.

Scarring: This salve seems to be an ointment of healing, but instead it inflicts [[/r 2d6 #points of severe burn damage]] points of severe burn damage. The damage can only be repaired by ointment of soothing, a cureall spell, or a wish.
Soothing: This salve cures the recipient of all burn damage, whether magical or normal.

Tanning: This salve causes the recipient's skin to turn a bright color [[1d6]] (1-red, 2-yellow, 3-orange, 4-blue, 5-green, or 6-brown). The effect cannot be removed but will wear off in [[1d4]] months.

items.description: Determines the type of magical ointment found, such as Blessing, Healing, Poison, or other effects.

items.name: Sword Primary Power

results.text: Primary Power: Detect shifting walls and rooms

items.description: Determines the primary power of a sword, including detection abilities or additional rolls for extraordinary powers.

items.description: Human woodland encounter.

results.text: NPC Party. One character of name level or greater, plus [[2d10]] low-level apprentices.

items.description: Determines the number of spells on the spell scroll. Roll for the level of each spell separately.

items.name: Dragon Control (gemstone)
items.description: Determines the type of gemstone dragon controlled.

items.name: Gem Value Table
items.description: Determines the exact type and value of a gem, based on the standard gem value ranges and probabilities.

items.name: Missile Talent 30%
items.description: Determines if a missile has a talent (30% chance). Roll on the Missile Talents table if successful.

items.name: Room with Alarm
items.description: The room is rigged with some type of alarm (sound, magical or mechanical) that can summon a special monster, open a dungeon door or have no functional effect at all.

results.text: The room has a stone protrusion with holes in it, fed by an underground steam vent. As soon as the characters enter the room, it starts whistling loudly. The sound continues for ten seconds and then stops.
The whistling sound has alerted something nearby. Roll on the appropriate encounter table  to determine the type of encounter.

A large stone suspended by a heavy chain slowly lowers to the floor, and a click is heard. A locked door or container somewhere in the dungeon has been unlocked. It is either the most recent lock they encountered or the next one they will come across.
A strange contraption in the center of the room spins for ten seconds when the characters enter the room. A wailing sound is heard when it stops.

items.name: AC Mod (Shield)
items.description: The armor class modifier for Shields. This table also rolls to determine of the shield has a special power.

items.name: Flyers (All Other)
items.description: Flyer encounter.

items.name: Empty Room
items.description: The room is empty except for cobwebs and random debris.

results.text: The room is empty except for a small sack lying near a skeleton in the corner. Roll on the appropriate treasure table for the dungeon level.
The room is empty except for cobwebs and random debris.

items.name: Extraordinary Power (NoReroll)
items.description: Determines the extraordinary power of a sword, including abilities like Clairvoyance, Telekinesis, or multiple rolls for additional powers.

results.text: Pursue: The men will chase the party off the lord's land or charge the characters a toll. This sum may vary depending on the personality of the lord, how wealthy the characters look, and other factors. Refusing to pay may result in the PCs being arrested, run off the land, or attacked. The DM can ignore this result if the castle owner is Lawful and the PCs have behaved well.
Ignore: No attempt is made to aid or hinder the party.
Friendly: The castle owner invites the party to stay. (This is not necessarily actual friendship; some NPCs may have evil intentions toward the unsuspecting party.)

items.name: Weapons Add. Mod. 10%
items.description: Determines if a weapon has an additional modifier. Roll on the Additional Weapon Mods (Misc) table if successful.

items.name: Animal Herd
items.description: Animal herd encounter.

items.name: Antidote Potion

results.text: Poisons from 7-HD (or lesser) creatures. Also works on Poison Potion.
Poisons from 15-HD (or lesser) creatures. Also works on Poison Potion.

items.description: Determines the effectiveness of an Antidote Potion, ranging from poisons caused by creatures with 3-HD to all poisons.

items.name: Extraordinary Power
items.description: Determines the extraordinary power of a sword, including abilities like Clairvoyance, Telekinesis, or multiple rolls for additional powers.

items.name: Potions
items.description: Table of magical potions with corresponding roll ranges.

items.name: Scrolls
items.description: Table to determine the type of scroll found, with references to subtables as needed. If a spell scroll is rolled then roll on the appropriate Spell Level table to determine the level of each spell.

items.name: Room Type
items.description: A randomly stocked dungeon room.

results.text: [[1d6]] Gems. Worth [[/r (1d6+1)*50 #Gold piece value of gem]] gold pieces each.  Roll for each gem separately.

items.name: Wishes Ring
items.description: Determines how many wishes the Wish Ring will grant, ranging from 1 to 4.

items.name: Room with Monster
items.description: The room has a one or more monsters in it.

results.text: Room has treasure! Roll on appropriate treasure table for dungeon level.
Lair! This room is part of a monster's lair. Roll on the appropriate encounter table to determine the type of monster and how many there are.
Encounter! One or more monsters are in this room. Roll on the appropriate wandering monster table.

items.name: Special Power 25%
items.description: Armor has 25% chance of having a special power.

items.name: NPC Adventurer Alignment
items.description: Adventurer alignment

results.text: Pursue: The men will chase the party off the lord's land or charge the characters a toll. This sum may vary depending on the personality of the lord, how wealthy the characters look, and other factors. Refusing to pay may result in the PCs being arrested, run off the land, or attacked. The DM can ignore this result if the castle owner is Lawful and the PCs have behaved well.
Ignore: No attempt is made to aid or hinder the party.
Friendly: The castle owner invites the party to stay. (This is not necessarily actual friendship; some NPCs may have evil intentions toward the unsuspecting party.)

items.name: Sword Primary Power (NoReroll)

results.text: Primary Power: Detect shifting walls and rooms

items.description: Determines the primary power of a sword, including detection abilities or additional rolls for extraordinary powers.

items.name: Dragon Control (normal)
items.description: Determines the type of gemstone dragon controlled.

items.name: Weapon Opponents
items.description: Determines the type of opponent a weapon is specially effective against.

items.name: Wands, Staves, and Rods

results.text: Wand of Enemy Detection (M): Contains [[3d10]] charges.
Wand of Lightning Bolts (M): Contains [[3d10]] charges.
Wand of Magic Detection (M): Contains [[3d10]] charges.
Wand of Metal Detection (M): Contains [[3d10]] charges.
Wand of Secret Door Detection (M): Contains [[3d10]] charges.
Wand of Trap Detection (M): Contains [[3d10]] charges.
Staff of the Druids (DR): Contains [[2d20]] charges.
Staff of an Element (M): Contains [[2d20]] charges.

items.description: Wands and staves are powerful magical tools, each with unique effects. Rods are versatile items without charges, often imbued with potent abilities.

items.name: Missiles (Class A)
items.description: Determines the magical bonus and quantity of Missiles (Class A). Additional talents may apply based on the roll.

items.name: Missile Weapons Range (+2)
items.description: Determines the range bonus for a magical missile weapon.

items.name: Swords (Class C)
items.description: Determines the type of sword (Class C) and its magical bonus.

items.name: Missile Talent 20%
items.description: Determines if a missile has a talent (20% chance). Roll on the Missile Talents table if successful.

items.name: Misc.Weapons (Adv.)
items.description: Generates miscellaneous weapons and their classes. Use the Magical Bonuses and Modifiers table for further customization.

items.name: Monster Reaction Roll
items.description: The referee determines monsters’ reaction to the party. Sometimes, circumstances make it obvious how a monster will react. Otherwise, the referee may roll on the table below to determine how a monster reacts to the party.

items.name: Misc. Weapons (Class C)
items.description: Determines the magic bonus and chance of additional modifiers for Class C weapons.

items.name: Missile Weapons & Missiles (Adv.)
items.description: Determines the type of missile weapon or missile found and its weapon class. Use the appropriate bonus table for additional properties.

items.name: Pit Trap
items.description: A section of the floor gives way, and one, some, or all characters must make a Dexterity check to see if they can avoid falling in. If they fail, they fall in, taking 1d4, 1d6, 1d8, or 1d10 damage. The pit may have something at the bottom, such as spikes for more damage, deep water, or a monster. It may be a chute, leading down for a one-way ride to the next dungeon level.

results.text: A six-foot deep pit trap. The fall does [[/r 1d4]] damage.
A ten-foot deep pit trap. The fall does [[/r 1d6]] damage.
A ten-foot deep pit trap with a few spikes at the bottom. The fall does [[/r 1d8]] damage.
A ten-foot deep pit trap lined with spikes at the bottom. The fall does [[/r 1d8+2]] damage.
A pit trap filled with water. The fall is twenty feet, but the only potential damage is to the character's items.
A pit trap with a chute leading to a room in the next level of the dungeon.

items.name: Missile Weapons Range (+5)
items.description: Determines the range bonus for a magical missile weapon.

results.text: [[1d6]] Jewelry. Worth [[/r 1d6*50 #Gold piece value of jewelry]] gold pieces each. Roll for each item of jewelry separately.  @Compendium[fade-compendiums.roll-table-compendium.RollTable.YTfrzt8Tsat7r6BU]

items.name: Spell Catching
items.description: Determines the range of spell levels that can be caught using Spell Catching.

items.name: Magic Armor
items.description: Determines the type of armor or shield found. Includes individual armors (e.g., leather, chain mail) and combinations (e.g., plate & shield).

items.name: Cursed Weapon Check
items.description: Check top see if the weapon is cursed. This is used for miscellaneous weapons.

items.name: City Encounter
items.description:
City Encounter

  • Clear daylight [[4d6*10]] yards

  • Dim Light* [[2d6*10]] yards

  • No light † [[1d4*10]] yards

* Or full darkness with infravision used.

† Or very poor visibility (heavy snow or fog, sandstorm, etc.).

items.name: Insects
items.description: Insect encounter.

items.name: AC Mod (Plate or Suit)
items.description: The armor class modifier for Plate Mail or Suit armor. This table also rolls to determine of the armor has a special power.

results.text: [[1d6]] Jewelry. Worth [[/r 1d8*50 #Gold piece value of jewelry]] gold pieces each. Roll for each item of jewelry separately.  @Compendium[fade-compendiums.roll-table-compendium.RollTable.YTfrzt8Tsat7r6BU]

items.name: Talisman of Elemental Travel
items.description: Determines the type of Talisman of Elemental Travel found, such as a Lesser Talisman for a single element or a Greater Talisman for all elements.

items.name: Missile Talents
items.description: Determines the specific talent of a magical missile, such as Biting, Stunning, or Wounding.

items.name: Special Power 30%
items.description: Armor has 30% chance of having a special power.

items.name: Additional Weapon Mods (Misc)
items.description: Determines additional modifiers for miscellaneous weapons. Use the result to adjust bonuses or roll on the Talents table for a specific talent.

items.name: AC Mod (Banded, Scale or Leather)
items.description: The armor class modifier for Banded, Scale or Leather armor. This table also rolls to determine if the armor has a special power.

items.name: Swamp Encounter
items.description:
Swamp Encounter

  • Clear daylight [[4d6*10]] yards

  • Dim Light* [[2d6*10]] yards

  • No light † [[1d4*10]] yards

* Or full darkness with infravision used.

† Or very poor visibility (heavy snow or fog, sandstorm, etc.).

items.name: Cursed Sword Check
items.description: Check top see if the sword is cursed.

items.name: Weapons Add. Mod. 30%
items.description: Determines if a weapon has an additional modifier. Roll on the Additional Weapon Mods (Misc) table if successful.

items.name: Magical Weapon (Basic)
items.description: The Magical Weapon (Basic) table is used to generate magical weapons for characters of levels 1–10. It includes three categories of weapons—missile weapons, swords, and miscellaneous weapons—along with their basic magical bonuses.

items.name: Weapons Add. Mod. 15%
items.description: Determines if a weapon has an additional modifier. Roll on the Additional Weapon Mods (Misc) table if successful.

items.name: Magical Items (Basic)
items.description: Determines the type of magical item found, such as a Potion, Scroll, Wand, or Sword.
